Posts.Content: May 8, 2010 07:21PM 1WonderWoman wrote: Thanks for the responses on the drains.   How long did you have drains in?  Also, thanks for the info on  the shower chair.  I really despise the idea of someone showering me!  I guess I will adjust for a few days.   I am a stomach sleeper and that is going to be the hardest part to get used to.  I picked up a bed rest pillow today and am hoping that helps me to garner a modicum of sleep in that first week.   My date might be moved to later in the week but I am not sure yet.  In any case, the closer the date, the more I just  can't wait for it to be over. Thanks for your help and responses- Liz
Posts.Title: I got my date...May 17 bmx..and now I have weird questions... 1WonderWoman Sherry9316

Posts.Content: May 8, 2010 08:45PM 1WonderWoman wrote: Sherry- Good question and I am going to answer, in full, in a lengthy that is going to be cathartic and perhaps not well accepted by some but so be it. This is my life and these are my reasons. Initially I need to point out my BS is a lovely woman, who is my age, and explained to me, in no uncertain, I have every option = lump, mx or bmx. I also must preface my reasoning with the fact that a good friend, Maureen, who's mom and sister died of bc, had a prophylactic mx. Finally, I saw my father dying a long, slow, miserable death from lung cancer and I even offered him one of my lungs. His was smoke-induced. If my father could have lived without his lungs, he would have gotten rid of them immediately. Now, I need my feet to walk and my eyes to see and my legs to transport me and my ears to hear but I DO NOT NEED MY BREASTS. They do NOTHING. They are simply coveted, with terribly misdirected interest, by those that find them enthralling. For this reason, many women have their entire identities tied up in these things. They are expendable. They decided to start trying to kill me so now they must go. Medically speaking, I was just about forced to do my first mammo at 38 years old. I don't like repeated exposure to even nominal amounts of radiation. So then I thought about the lumpectomy and the radiation requirement. IF the margins are not clear we have to start marching on now to mx and chemo etc.. Additionally, with an mx, if something is going on in the other breast the radiation option is now diminished. So now here I am *potentially* back in the medical industrial complex asking God "why me" and having more and more and more surgeries, pokes, prods etc... . Ideally let's say the lumpectomy worked for me, as it seems to have for Janet Reno. In any case, now, at 40 years old, if I live to 50 I have at least 20 mammograms to look forward to. I already said I did not like it to begin with so I don't want all that mess and why would I? I don't need my breasts; I am not milking anyone. So why would I want to go through all of this crap to keep my breasts that I don't need? Am I missing something? Additionally, the recurrence rate with lumpectomy is 10-15% or somewhere along those lines. Personally I, in my mind, think recurrence is more like 50% unless the cancer cells stand up and announce themselves when the surgeon cuts me open so she can't get every last one. Instead, cancer does not announce itself and us common folk believe when it gets some air at it, it likes to race around and hide , a like a kid on a steady diet of sugar. These scenarios are just too spooky for me. If it was my leg, I would have to do everything but these are boobs! I am also planning a hysterectomy next year so I don't give it anymore estrogen-friendly places to park it's miserable ass. Finally, the preponderance of women seem to be really enthralled with their boobs. I never loved mine. That is a very, very, very small part of this. What I would ask everyone who is hanging onto their breasts what precipitates their interest in doing so? Are they helping you breathe? What are they doing for you when you feel compelled to hang onto them especially when they are sick? Our breasts have decided, for reasons unknown, to manufacture cancer. On that note, I deeply suspect, like most twins, my breasts will share everything, including cancer. They say this one has been growing for 5 years. I am not waiting for find out if it is already in the other one. Why would I? Finally, I like working. I like the company I work for and I like the trading markets and our economy, with all it's gyrations. I don't want to be sitting in some hospital regularly because I could not get rid of my boobs. I have some living to do and even though all the hawkish might roll in about how bmx is not a ticket to cancer freedom, bmx is the best way I can bring my recurrence rate as low as possible. I like those odds.
Posts.Title: I got my date...May 17 bmx..and now I have weird questions... 1WonderWoman Sherry9316

Posts.Content: May 9, 2010 10:56AM 1WonderWoman wrote: Sherrie- It is very difficult for all of us with bc to be in the position of having to consider removing our breasts anyway never mind all the other issues.   In addition, removal,especially if it is invasive may not even be enough to evict it.  I just have to go with the most prudent, safest possible option for me.   If I was 70 I might think about this differently but having just turned 40, as far as I am concerned there is only 1 decision.   My breasts are a very, very small part of my existence.   There is a lot more for me to be concerned with.   I hope no one reading my posts gets the impression this was an easy decision because it definitely was not.   Like I have said before, our disease is in God's hands; our support is in each other's hands.  I feel it is also my responsibility to be a role model for women who have yet to join us.   There is life beyond breasts. Liz
Posts.Title: I got my date...May 17 bmx..and now I have weird questions... 1WonderWoman Sherry9316

Posts.Content: May 16, 2010 02:54PM 1WonderWoman wrote: Hello all- Tamin-yes, you were successful and I responded As for my surgery, the date is being changed as, suffice it to say, ther was a "paperwork" problem largely involving lack of precertification and the surgeon and her office staff being unable to accept directions on how paperwork needed to be handled to protect all our interests.  In addition, the BS yelling at me 3 days before surgery, while on speakerphone, in front of 2 friends and a poor census worker who was about 75 years old and flabbergasted, was so grotesquely unprofessional it bordered on incomprehensible. As of tomorrow, I will know a lot more about the way this was being structured and I am going to blog my experience to help other neophytes.   For most of you, in some way or another, be it through spouses or family members etc... are very familiar with the paperwork vortex and insurance co precert navigation etc.. but as a relatively healthy person who has not had a surgery in 23 years, since I was 17, I have no clue about all of this business which also means I can be easily mislead.   For anyone interested, I do have a blog.  I will list my experience and give out the address to interested parties once I finish this part of it.  I need to find out so much more about this amorphous structuring of this very expensive and inpatient procedure.  To all: please be aware we are in an awful economy there are people being advantageous and having bc, rather than protecting us, makes us super vulnerable.   Proceed with caution and make sure your insurance company knows everything and is in the loop.  Don't put your in the position of finding out a few days before surgery your insurance co had no clue you were having the surgery.   Tread lightly and carry a big stick, girls!!!!!!!
Posts.Title: I got my date...May 17 bmx..and now I have weird questions... 1WonderWoman Sherry9316

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2010 12:01PM 1WonderWoman wrote: First, I have to thank God for the this website and for Al Gore giving us the internet!  Joking!  In any case, we are all just dotted lines to each other and I am so grateful for the information and the exchange on this site.  I don't have a familial support system so I am grateful for you all ;)  >>>Texas wrote: As others have said, this is a very personal decision. As far as the odds, the mastectomy will dramatically lower your chance of recurrence in the breasts but that's not to say that your chances aren't already quite low.<< This is very, very true.  I also started to realize and, again, I just found out, that I am responding to this 1mm, Stage 1 ductal invasive malignant item as if this were 1970.   Medicine has come a long way, and my convoluted relationship with my breasts aside (!), I think I owe it to women, both younger and older, who are not so prepared to give up their breasts and who want options.  I have been leaning a bit more toward a lumpectomy and follow ups.  Do I love the notion of just getting rid of them?  Sort of!  I have not seen any pictures, been exposed to anyone who has a double with reconstruction and I have so many questions about what they will look like, lack of feeling etc.. it is not so easy to decide.  More importantly, however, if I can just get the lumpectomy done, and give medicine a shot, that might be an option I take on behalf of all women, similarly situated. My feeling is if I get one more "dirty" mammo I would just elect surgery.  One of the other lurking thoughts I had is health insurance and my age.  I am 40...that is a long way from the "natural" end and with health insurance so front-and=center, and spiraling into a baby-boomer-aging abyss, I am concerned about being negated if I did not get a double.  I am still confused and with so many questions but your input is so collectively helpful, I can't even express it in words.  I will continue to ruminate!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and I need advice! 1WonderWoman goodvibesonly

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2010 11:47AM 1WonderWoman wrote: Sunflowers- Thanks for your response as it was very helpful.  I, too, have that innate feeling I need to do the bilat.  How long has it been since your's?  Did you have a baseline MRI or, more to this point, do you know how reoccurrence would be detected b/c of implants?  Also what made you go gel over saline?   My BS has simply discussed saline.  I am seeing a PS tomorrow afternoon.  My BS also said a bilate brings my chances of seeing this again to less than 1% but doing a lump is 15-20% chance and personally, as they are only pretty sure this thing started growing some 4 - 5 years ago (mine is very low grade, non-aggressive), there is no way for me to know it hasn't already set up surreptitious camp in the other breast at this point!  I won't know until that becomes clear on a mammo and it is all too much drama for me and for what?  To hang onto fat sacs hanging off my chest, producing poison that is trying to kill me?! Right now I liken my breasts to old, burned out buildlings in the South Bronx that are loaded with junkies etc.. and the only way to permanently rectify the situation is to take down the buildings!  I feel at least in this way I have the best chance possible to avoid this happening again.  I like those odds.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and I need advice! 1WonderWoman goodvibesonly

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 11:41AM 1WonderWoman wrote: TO ALL OF YOU:  THANK YOU ALL SO MUCH!  I can't believe what an outpouring of support.  Consequently, and just so you know, I learned my first discussion board lesson yesterday which is I cannot post more than 5 times in any given day so I was reading all of your great responses, and making a doc in word with things I need to keep in mind, but was frustrated because I could not respond!  This is an emotional, hot topic so the 5-post-a-day limit makes sense. The stories have been wonderful and nothing short of great. Sweaty-It is so funny some of the things you point out about breasts and sex so I will address that now with a deeply personal anecdote: I was 18 and going out with this guy and, upon intimacy, he asked me, quite pointedly, if mine were "alive" or "dead!!!!"   After a bit of ambivalence, I answered my 19 yo boyfriend by saying "they are dead!"  I never had any response to them sexually..at all.  In addition, I like to work out and my breasts are large which is yet another issue for me.  I can't even really consider having 1 removed because is so large they would not match.   This part is a complete side bar but one I am sure you can all respect: I was at my brother's hockey game at like 8 years old and my mother was saying, quite jokingly, to her friend's, relative to the ice cold rink at 8AM, "well, girls, at least we have knee warmers!"  This is the other thing with this one now maligned watermelon hanging off of my chest is the fact that they are just cumbersome for me.  I don't love them and I never did.  When I used to run, in Central Park, I had to tape them down and use a sports bra.  In addition, as heterosexual as I am, I am so aggravated with the unnecessary level of male attention they are paid that saying goodbye is not such a problem for me.  It is the potential for necrosis, lymphedema (masectomy or not), questions about how they even find recurring BC if I have fake boobs and how I would adapt to the numbness.  In the end, however, I am still gathering information but am secretly looking forward to saying goodbye to them. I don't think I have the mental wherewithall to put a misplaced sense of concern on my deep ambivalence toward my breasts to begin with ahead of knowing that I have greatly, greatly reduced my chances of ever having this crap again...at least not in this form anyway!   I just don't think I can hang onto these, long-term, and keep going every 6 months for mammos to see if "it is back."   That is too much for me especially when I don't love these jokers to begin with!   This thing getting sick on me is sort of like hanging onto a stock you didn't really like too much to begin with and this is the bad earnings report you needed to SELL!  Sorry...too many years in the financial industry!  I appreciate everyone's responses.  You all are such a collective, and deeply considerate, wealth of knowledge, I feel blessed.   At times I lament the lack of immediate family in the area etc...but I really prefer to do my own thing and the melodrama of my sister and brother lurking about, being scary about this dx, is too taxing in and of itself!   My mom is in a nursing home and barely speaks and my dad died of lung cancer (smoking related) some 10 years ago so I have friends and a strong will.   I may have breast cancer today but I could also be hit by a car tomorrow and we just don't know what is going to take us so we carry on.  BC is not the death knoll it once was and I am going to live until I am not living anymore :)
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and I need advice! 1WonderWoman goodvibesonly

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2010 11:00PM 1WonderWoman wrote: Mich-M- Thank you soo much!  It happened again today!  I am just frenetic right now as I have a few weeks to decide, per my BS, although she was not definitive.   Consequently, and so I don't use one of my 5 for today without asking a question, I might like to take a month so I can adequately check out PS etc... and really to just get prepared for this... I feel like 2 weeks is not enough and with a low grade, albeit IDC, Stage 1, does anyone have any advice?  I know, clearly, the sooner the better but I am just trying to deal with all of this...who knows?  I might be so burnt out on the whole topic in another I will be begging for my bilat!  Oh yeah..does anyone have any info on working out BEFORE surgery?  It just so happens I took a week off in February strictly to put my Weider Pro together in the basement of my new house and got the flat bench (I used to body build) and started LIFTING again.  Of course I do pec deck and I have stopped doing that as I can only assume maximum flexibility of the pec muscles will be optimal?  I will see a ps, my first interview, tomorrow.   On another topic, frenetic Liz travels along(!), does anyone here remember any SIGNS they had this crap?!   I was getting pain in my breast and I have been wicked tired but as I have hashimoto's, I just figured time for another blood work-up.   I am trying to figure out how this has been, in a very quiet way, having an effect on me.   Anyone with any thoughts on this would be great.  I mean this stuff kills us so therefore it must present itself in some way prior do dx and now that I know, I can't help by recount how this has/may have been manifesting.  I have an inquisitive mind! Thanks, girls!  Ya' all are the best! Liz
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and I need advice! 1WonderWoman goodvibesonly

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2010 11:42PM 1WonderWoman wrote: Jess- In *the* very month before dx, which was last Friday!, I kept calling my doc's office saying I am so tired, very tired, lethargic, thyroid must be acting up.  I went to see him twice, whining about this fatigue that was just enveloping me.  I think this stuff was just introducing itself!   I mean clearly, and to avoid others getting nervous, being extremely tired was what I consider to be one of my major symptoms but that can be a symptom for sooo many things, we need not read into that!  OH...now I remember: right after the ultrasound where I just knew that woman saw something she did not like, and was nearly pushing that ultrasound device THROUGH my chest, trying to get the best shots, is right about the time my tiredness increased.  She blew it off, staing it was a clogged milk duct and b/c of my age and no kids, classic etc.. She was believable but in retrospect, I don't think she wanted to scare me. I think I would like a month.  I was dx'd on 4/16 and I think 5/15 (my now decased Dad's bday *lung cancer induced by smoking way too much for way too long*) is a good target date.   I am single and I need to get my house straight, home health aides hired, clothes...etc.. and on the clothing topic, any suggestions?   With a bilat, once they fill, no more bras but in the interim, and for the purposes of appearance uniformity and civility (!), will I need a mastectomy bra and some of the gel inserts?   Something else: these camisoles with built in pockets are pockets for the gel inserts?  I was confused...I did not know if they were for the post-op drainage tubes.  Thanks everyone...wow...I am so lucky to have this site and these boards with such a wealth of knowledge.  Liz

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2010 02:18PM 1WonderWoman wrote: Beesie- thank you so much for your very thoughtful response.  My sense is about having them removed to nearly totally negate the chance for a new primary or reoccurence.  My problem with an immediate mastectomy is that, as you indicate, the pathology is unknown.  We have no idea if it spread to the nodes or what we are dealing with.  In the event I have a bi, as a partial isn't even a consideration, I am doing it to save my health.  If, however, I emerged from surgery and found out it had spread, my mastectomy is for naught.  I really need to know if it has spread and I need to visit with plastic surgeons and get some idea of what reconstructed breasts look like and what I can expect.  I understand they won't have feeling, etc.. but I really will forego sexual joy of breasts to save my life.   I would never, however, consider a mastectomy and no reconstruction.  That is NOT on the menu for me.  They talked to me about putting pumps under my breast muscles and that over the course of 3-6 months they would fill which seems an inordinately long period of time for my breasts to fill with saline?!   I have too many questions and only a few weeks to get answers.   How is it that people getting boob jobs come flying out of the hospital in 1 day with gargantuan breasts and I, having elected this because of breast cancer, will be having to slowly fill up over the course of several months?  Why is it also that the skin from my breasts would not be maintained and just have implants put in?  I am so deeply and profoundly confused.  In addition, getting appointments to talk to these plastic surgeons is not easy.  I thank God for my GP, however, who I love more than words can express.  He encouraged me to get an ultrasound because I did not want to go for the mammo (have an issue with being exposed to radiation..what a fool I was being!).  I was on time for my every-2-year mammo, however. I am sorry to sound so confused and lost but, no joke, I am lost.   I am confused beyond belief.  I just think taking my boobs off and afterwards finding out it has spread is just too much to bear all at once.  What would be the sense of removal of my breasts if it has spread.  I am certainly not clairvoyant therefore I am clueless as to what the results of this lymph business will be.  That is the stumbling block for me.

Wow...the entire medical industrial complex has come so very, very far!!!!!
